info.title: Cognite API
info.description: This is the reference documentation for the Cognite API. Here you can see an overview of all methods available through the API.

id.description: Generated id of the time series

externalId.description: Externaly supplied id of the time series

isString.description: Whether the time series is string valued or not.

metadata.description: Additional metadata. String key -> String value.

unit.description: The physical unit of the time series.

assetId.description: Asset that this time series belongs to.

isStep.description: Whether the time series is a step series or not.

securityCategories.description: Security categories required in order to access this time series.

items.description: Security categories required in order to access this time series.

createdTime.description: Time when this time-series is created in CDP in milliseconds since Jan 1, 1970.

lastUpdatedTime.description: The latest time when this time-series is updated in CDP in milliseconds since Jan 1, 1970.

id.description: Id of the timeseries to post the datapoints to

externalId.description: External id of the timeseries to post the datapoints to (Only if id is not set)

timestamp.description: The data timestamp in milliseconds since the epoch (Jan 1, 1970).

value.description: The data value. Can be String or numeric depending on the metric

id.description: Id of the timeseries to query

externalId.description: External id of the timeseries to query (Only if id is not set)

start.description: Get datapoints after this time. Format is N[timeunit]-ago where timeunit is w,d,h,m,s. Example: '2d-ago' will get everything that is up to 2 days old. Can also send time in ms since epoch.

end.description: Get datapoints up to this time. The format is the same as for start.

limit.description: Return up to this number of datapoints.

aggregates.description: The aggregates to be returned.  Use default if null. An empty string must be sent to get raw data if the default is a set of aggregates.

items.description: The aggregates to be returned.  Use default if null. An empty string must be sent to get raw data if the default is a set of aggregates.

granularity.description: The granularity size and granularity of the aggregates.

includeOutsidePoints.description: Whether to include the last datapoint before the requested time period,and the first one after the requested period. This can be useful for interpolating data. Not available for aggregates.

items.description: Input alias for the function query

id.description: The id of the timeseries that this alias references

alias.description: The string value that is referenced in the function expression

aggregate.description: The aggregate to fetch for this alias, empty means fetch non-aggregated data. Aggregate values will be interpolated for periods with no ground data. There are known inaccuracies in how the average value is interpolated.

granularity.description: The granularity of the aggregates, only relevant if property 'aggregate' is specified

items.description: Parameters describing a query for datapoints.

start.description: Get datapoints after this time. Format is N[timeunit]-ago where timeunit is w,d,h,m,s. Example: '2d-ago' will get everything that is up to 2 days old. Can also send time in ms since epoch. Default '0'.

end.description: Get datapoints up to this time. Same format as for start. Default 'now'.

limit.description: Return up to this number of datapoints. Default 100.

aggregates.description: The aggregates to be applied. If both this field and the a query item aggregate field is left blank, un-aggregated data will be returned for that query.

items.description: The aggregates to be applied. If both this field and the a query item aggregate field is left blank, un-aggregated data will be returned for that query.

granularity.description: The time granularity size and unit to aggregate over. For example '1h' for one hour.

includeOutsidePoints.description: Whether to include the last datapoint before the requested time period,and the first one after the requested period. This can be useful for interpolating data. Not available for aggregates.

DatapointsMultiQuery.description: Parameters describing a query for multiple datapoints. If fields in individual datapoint query items are omitted, values from the multiquery are used instead. For example, you can provide a default limit for all items (that do not have a limit set) by setting the limit field in the multiquery.

externalId.description: External id of the timeseries to post the datapoints to (Only if id is not set)

end.description: Get datapoints up to this time. The format is the same as for start.

limit.description: Return up to this number of datapoints.

aggregates.description: The aggregates to be returned.  Use default if null. An empty string must be sent to get raw data if the default is a set of aggregates.

items.description: The aggregates to be returned.  Use default if null. An empty string must be sent to get raw data if the default is a set of aggregates.

granularity.description: The granularity size and granularity of the aggregates.

includeOutsidePoints.description: Whether to include the last datapoint before the requested time period,and the first one after the requested period. This can be useful for interpolating data. Not available for aggregates.

items.description: Input alias for the function query

id.description: The id of the timeseries that this alias references

alias.description: The string value that is referenced in the function expression

aggregate.description: The aggregate to fetch for this alias, empty means fetch non-aggregated data. Aggregate values will be interpolated for periods with no ground data. There are known inaccuracies in how the average value is interpolated.

granularity.description: The granularity of the aggregates, only relevant if property 'aggregate' is specified

DatapointsQuery.description: Parameters describing a query for datapoints.

FunctionInputAlias.description: Input alias for the function query

id.description: The id of the timeseries that this alias references

alias.description: The string value that is referenced in the function expression

aggregate.description: The aggregate to fetch for this alias, empty means fetch non-aggregated data. Aggregate values will be interpolated for periods with no ground data. There are known inaccuracies in how the average value is interpolated.

granularity.description: The granularity of the aggregates, only relevant if property 'aggregate' is specified

LatestDataBeforeRequest.description: Describes the latest query. One and only one of id and externalId must be set.

id.description: Id of the timeseries to get the latest value for

externalId.description: External id of the timeseries to get the latest value for (Only if id is not set)

before.description: Get first datapoint before this time. Format is N[timeunit]-ago where timeunit is w,d,h,m,s. Example: '2d-ago' will get everything that is up to 2 days old. Can also send time in ms since epoch.

items.description: List of latest queries
Describes the latest query. One and only one of id and externalId must be set.

id.description: Id of the timeseries to get the latest value for

externalId.description: External id of the timeseries to get the latest value for (Only if id is not set)

before.description: Get first datapoint before this time. Format is N[timeunit]-ago where timeunit is w,d,h,m,s. Example: '2d-ago' will get everything that is up to 2 days old. Can also send time in ms since epoch.

DatapointsDeleteRequest.description: Describes the latest query. One and only one of id and externalId must be set.

id.description: Id of the timeseries to get the latest value for

externalId.description: External id of the timeseries to get the latest value for (Only if id is not set)

exclusiveEnd.description: If set, the first datapoint after inclusiveBegin to not delete. If not set, only deletes the datapoint at inclusiveBegin.

items.description: List of deletes
Describes the latest query. One and only one of id and externalId must be set.

id.description: Id of the timeseries to get the latest value for

externalId.description: External id of the timeseries to get the latest value for (Only if id is not set)

exclusiveEnd.description: If set, the first datapoint after inclusiveBegin to not delete. If not set, only deletes the datapoint at inclusiveBegin.

IdLookup.description: Object is required to provide only one from two available attributes (one or another). Id field maps to server side ID while externalId to user set identifier.

items.description: List of ID objects

metadata.description: Filter out timeseries that do not match these metadata fields and values (case-sensitive). Format is {"key1":"value1","key2":"value2"}.

assetIds.description: Filter out time series that are not linked to any of these assets.

assetSubtrees.description: Filter out time series that are not linked to assets in the subtree rooted at these assets. Format is [12,345,6,7890].

createdTime.description: Filter out time series with createdTime before this. Format is milliseconds since epoch.

lastUpdatedTime.description: Filter out time series with lastUpdatedTime before this. Format is milliseconds since epoch.

name.description: Prefix and fuzzy search on name.

description.description: Prefix and fuzzy search on description.

query.description: Search on name and description using wildcard search on each of the words (separated by spaces). Retrieves results where at least one word must match. Example: '*some* *other*'

metadata.description: Filter out timeseries that do not match these metadata fields and values (case-sensitive). Format is {"key1":"value1","key2":"value2"}.

assetIds.description: Filter out time series that are not linked to any of these assets.

assetSubtrees.description: Filter out time series that are not linked to assets in the subtree rooted at these assets. Format is [12,345,6,7890].

lastUpdatedTime.description: Filter out time series with lastUpdatedTime before this. Format is milliseconds since epoch.

name.description: Prefix and fuzzy search on name.

description.description: Prefix and fuzzy search on description.

query.description: Search on name and description using wildcard search on each of the words (separated by spaces). Retrieves results where at least one word must match. Example: '*some* *other*'

sort.description: Field to be sorted. If not specified, results are sorted by relevance score.

dir.description: Sort direction: descending or ascending. Only applicable if sort is specified. Default 'desc'.

limit.description: Return up to this many results. Maximum is 1000. Default is 25.

offset.description: Offset from the first result. Sum of limit and offset must not exceed 1000. Default is 0.

boostName.description: Whether or not boosting name field. This option is experimental and can be changed.

NullableSinglePatch.description: Change that will be applied to metadata. String key -> String value.

NullableSinglePatchLong.description: Change that will be applied to assetId.

NullableSinglePatchString.description: Change that will be applied to description.

ArrayPatchLong.description: Change that will be applied to securityCategories.

get.description: Retrieves a list of all time series in a project, sorted by name alphabetically. Parameters can be used to select a subset of time series. This operation supports pagination.

parameters.name: limit
parameters.description: Limits the number of results to be returned. The maximum results returned by the server is 1000 even if the limit specified is larger.

parameters.name: includeMetadata
parameters.description: Decide if the metadata field should be returned or not.

parameters.name: cursor
parameters.description: Cursor for paging through time series.

parameters.name: assetId
parameters.description: Get time series related to this asset.

200.description: A list of time series in lexicographic order.

post.description: Retrieves the details of multiple time series within the same project given the project id and a list of time series ids. Time series are returned in the same order as they appeared in the list of ids in the request.

requestBody.description: List of time series IDs to retrieve

items.description: List of ID objects
Object is required to provide only one from two available attributes (one or another). Id field maps to server side ID while externalId to user set identifier.

200.description: List of time-series matching the ids.

post.description:
Updates multiple time series objects within a single project at the same time. This operation supports partial updates, meaning that fields not specified in the request are left unchanged on the object.

For primitive fields (String, Long Int), use 'set': 'value' to update value; use 'setNull': true to set that field to null.

For the Json Array field (e.g. securityCategories), use 'set': [value1, value2] to update value; use 'add': [v1, v2] to add values to current list of values; use 'remove': [v1, v2] to remove these values from current list of values if exist.

post.summary: Insert a list of data points into multiple time series.
post.description: Inserts multiple data points into multiple time series in the same project.

id.description: Id of the timeseries to post the datapoints to

externalId.description: External id of the timeseries to post the datapoints to (Only if id is not set)

timestamp.description: The data timestamp in milliseconds since the epoch (Jan 1, 1970).

value.description: The data value. Can be String or numeric depending on the metric

404.description: Ids or external ids not found

items.description: Ids or ExternalIds which are not found

post.summary: Retrieve data points from multiple time series
post.description: Retrieves a list of data points from multiple time series in the same project. This operation supports aggregation but not pagination. This operation is also accessible using GET if the post body is supplied as a query parameter named postBody.

requestBody.description: The list of DatapointsQueries to perform.

id.description: Id of the timeseries to query

externalId.description: External id of the timeseries to query (Only if id is not set)

start.description: Get datapoints after this time. Format is N[timeunit]-ago where timeunit is w,d,h,m,s. Example: '2d-ago' will get everything that is up to 2 days old. Can also send time in ms since epoch.

end.description: Get datapoints up to this time. The format is the same as for start.

limit.description: Return up to this number of datapoints.

aggregates.description: The aggregates to be returned.  Use default if null. An empty string must be sent to get raw data if the default is a set of aggregates.

items.description: The aggregates to be returned.  Use default if null. An empty string must be sent to get raw data if the default is a set of aggregates.

granularity.description: The granularity size and granularity of the aggregates.

includeOutsidePoints.description: Whether to include the last datapoint before the requested time period,and the first one after the requested period. This can be useful for interpolating data. Not available for aggregates.

items.description: Input alias for the function query

id.description: The id of the timeseries that this alias references

alias.description: The string value that is referenced in the function expression

aggregate.description: The aggregate to fetch for this alias, empty means fetch non-aggregated data. Aggregate values will be interpolated for periods with no ground data. There are known inaccuracies in how the average value is interpolated.

granularity.description: The granularity of the aggregates, only relevant if property 'aggregate' is specified

items.description: Parameters describing a query for datapoints.

start.description: Get datapoints after this time. Format is N[timeunit]-ago where timeunit is w,d,h,m,s. Example: '2d-ago' will get everything that is up to 2 days old. Can also send time in ms since epoch. Default '0'.

end.description: Get datapoints up to this time. Same format as for start. Default 'now'.

limit.description: Return up to this number of datapoints. Default 100.

aggregates.description: The aggregates to be applied. If both this field and the a query item aggregate field is left blank, un-aggregated data will be returned for that query.

items.description: The aggregates to be applied. If both this field and the a query item aggregate field is left blank, un-aggregated data will be returned for that query.

granularity.description: The time granularity size and unit to aggregate over. For example '1h' for one hour.

includeOutsidePoints.description: Whether to include the last datapoint before the requested time period,and the first one after the requested period. This can be useful for interpolating data. Not available for aggregates.

schema.description: Parameters describing a query for multiple datapoints. If fields in individual datapoint query items are omitted, values from the multiquery are used instead. For example, you can provide a default limit for all items (that do not have a limit set) by setting the limit field in the multiquery.

200.description: Lists of datapoints for the given queries.

id.description: Id of the timeseries the datapoints belong to

externalId.description: External id of the timeseries the datapoints belong to (Only if id is not set)

timestamp.description: The data timestamp in milliseconds since the epoch (Jan 1, 1970).

value.description: The data value. Can be String or numeric depending on the metric

average.description: The integral average value in the aggregate period

max.description: The maximum value in the aggregate period

min.description: The minimum value in the aggregate period

count.description: The number of datapoints in the aggregate period

sum.description: The sum of the datapoints in the aggregate period

interpolation.description: The interpolated value of the series in the beginning of the aggregate

stepInterpolation.description: The last value before or at the beginning of the aggregate.

continuousVariance.description: The variance of the interpolated underlying function.

discreteVariance.description: The variance of the datapoint values.

totalVariation.description: The total variation of the interpolated underlying function.

items.description: Ids or ExternalIds which are not found

post.summary: Retrieve the latest data point in a time series
post.description: Retrieves the single latest data point in a time series.

requestBody.description: The list of get latest queries to perform.

items.description: List of latest queries
Describes the latest query. One and only one of id and externalId must be set.

id.description: Id of the timeseries to get the latest value for

externalId.description: External id of the timeseries to get the latest value for (Only if id is not set)

before.description: Get first datapoint before this time. Format is N[timeunit]-ago where timeunit is w,d,h,m,s. Example: '2d-ago' will get everything that is up to 2 days old. Can also send time in ms since epoch.

200.description: A list of responses. Each response contains a list containing a single point, the most recent datapoint, or an empty list if no points found.

id.description: Id of the timeseries the datapoints belong to

externalId.description: External id of the timeseries the datapoints belong to (Only if id is not set)

timestamp.description: The data timestamp in milliseconds since the epoch (Jan 1, 1970).

value.description: The data value. Can be String or numeric depending on the metric

average.description: The integral average value in the aggregate period

max.description: The maximum value in the aggregate period

min.description: The minimum value in the aggregate period

count.description: The number of datapoints in the aggregate period

sum.description: The sum of the datapoints in the aggregate period

interpolation.description: The interpolated value of the series in the beginning of the aggregate

stepInterpolation.description: The last value before or at the beginning of the aggregate.

continuousVariance.description: The variance of the interpolated underlying function.

discreteVariance.description: The variance of the datapoint values.

totalVariation.description: The total variation of the interpolated underlying function.

404.description: The time series does not exist.

items.description: Ids or ExternalIds which are not found

post.description: Perform a set of delete requests

requestBody.description: The list of deletes to perform.

items.description: List of deletes
Describes the latest query. One and only one of id and externalId must be set.

id.description: Id of the timeseries to get the latest value for

externalId.description: External id of the timeseries to get the latest value for (Only if id is not set)

exclusiveEnd.description: If set, the first datapoint after inclusiveBegin to not delete. If not set, only deletes the datapoint at inclusiveBegin.

items.description: Ids or ExternalIds which are not found

tags.name: Time series
tags.description:
A time series consists of a sequence of data points connected to a single asset. 

For example: A water pump asset can have a temperature time series that records a data point in units of C every second. 

A single asset can have several time series. The water pump could have additional time series measuring pressure within the pump, rpm, flow volume, power consumption, and more.

Time series store data points as either number or strings. This is controlled by the is_string flag on the time series object. Numerical data points can be aggregated before they are returned from a query (e.g., to find the average temperature for a day). String data points, on the other hand, cannot be aggregated by CDP, but can store arbitrary information like states (e.g. open/closed) or more complex information (JSON).

Cognite stores discrete data points, but the underlying process measured by the data points can vary continuously. When interpolating between data points, we can either assume that each value stays the same until the next measurement, or that it linearly changes between the two measurements. This is controlled by the is_step flag on the time series object. For example, if we estimate the average over a time containing two data points, the average will either be close to the first (is step) or close to the mean of the two (not is step).

A data point stores a single piece of information, a number or a string, associated with a specific time. Data points are identified by their timestamps, measured in milliseconds since the unix epoch -- 00:00, January 1st, 1970. Milliseconds is the finest time resolution supported by CDP i.e. fractional milliseconds are not supported. Leap seconds are not counted.

Numerical data points can be aggregated before they are retrieved from CDP. This allows for faster queries by reducing the amount of data transferred. You can aggregate data points by specifying one or more aggregates (e.g. average, minimum, maximum) as well as the time granularity over which the aggregates should be applied (e.g. 1h for one hour).

Aggregates are aligned to the start time modulo the granularity unit. For example, if you ask for daily average temperatures since monday afternoon last week, the first aggregated data point will contain averages for monday, the second for tuesday, etc. Determining aggregate alignment without considering data point timestamps allows CDP to pre-calculate aggregates (e.g. to quickly return daily average temperatures for a year). As a consequence, aggregating over 60 minutes can return a different result that aggregating over 1 hour because the two queries will be aligned differently.Deprecation warning: In the future, CDP will phase out name as a unique identifier for time series, and instead use a primary key of externalId. Time series names must currently be unique across across all time series in the same project. In version 1 of CDP, time series names will no longer be unique.
